abstract.t: This specification defines the Simple Update Protocol, a mechanism by which content feed publishers can signal to feed consumers that certain feeds have been updated.

section.title: Introduction
section.t: SUP (Simple Update Protocol) consists of a notification format that feed publishers can use to alert consumers that one or more content feeds have been recently updated. The presence of a SUP feed allows for increased efficiency, and decreased latency, by reducing or eliminating the need for consumers to frequently poll each underlying feed individually.

section.title: Notational Conventions
section.t: The key words "MUST", "MUST NOT", "REQUIRED", "SHALL", "SHALL NOT", "SHOULD", "SHOULD NOT", "RECOMMENDED", "MAY", and "OPTIONAL" in this document are to be interpreted as described in .

section.title: Design Considerations
section.t: SUP feeds are designed to be easy for publishers to create, increasing in benefit as the number of underlying feeds grows. Consumers that read a large number of feeds from a given publisher, such as a blog aggregators, hosted feed readers, or intermediary publishers, will similarly benefit most from using the SUP feed to reduce polling rates for individual feeds and query only when updates are available.

section.title: Overview
section.t: Publishers that produce large numbers of content feeds can aggregate a list of feeds that have changed over a given time period and publish this list as a SUP Feed to consumers. Each underlying content feed is identified by an opaque token called a SUP ID, which consumers can associate with a previously-seen feed URL, which can then be re-queried as necessary. Publishers use the X-SUP-ID HTTP header and the atom:link element with each content feed to announce the feed's unique SUP ID and the location of the SUP feed itself.

section.title: SUP Feed
section.t: [Ed: Perhaps consider changing the name of this to 'Updates Feed' to reduce redundancy. Also, "feed" itself might be a misleading term, as each new version tends to overwrite the last completely. Perhaps "Updates Document" is better?]
A SUP feed consists of a document of type 'application/json' containing a single top-level JSON Object, mapping a set of well-known keys to well-defined values, as defined below.
Consumers SHOULD ignore any unanticipated keys in the JSON document and continue to parse the expected values as intended.
The overall structure of the SUP feed is as follows:

section.title: The 'updates' field
section.t: A JSON List of two-element JSON Lists, each containing the tuple (SUP ID, Update ID).
This field is REQUIRED. It MAY contain an empty list if no content feeds have been updated in the given interval.

section.title: The 'period' field
section.t: A positive integer representing the the duration of time covered by this feed, in seconds.
This field is REQUIRED.

section.title: The 'since_time' field
section.t: An formatted string representing the start time of the interval covered by this feed.
This field is REQUIRED.

section.title: The 'updated_time' field
section.t: An formatted string representing the end time of the interval covered by this feed.
This field is REQUIRED.
The delta in seconds between the 'start_time' and the 'updated_time' fields MUST be equal to or greater than the duration indicated by the 'period' field.

section.title: The 'available_periods' field
section.t: A JSON Object mapping time periods (in seconds) to URLs where an additional SUP feed of the corresponding duration may be found.
This field is OPTIONAL.

section.title: SUP ID
section.t: [Ed: Perhaps consider changing this to 'Resource Id' to reduce redundancy. And more generally, consider calling the underlying documents "resources" rather than "feeds", as the SUP technique isn't specific to only Atom or RSS content.]
A SUP ID is a short opaque string used to identify a individual content feed. A single feed MUST always map to a single, stable SUP ID, but different feeds MAY occasionally share the same SUP ID.

Consumers SHOULD NOT attempt to parse or interpret the contents of the string, but instead should maintain their own mapping of SUP IDs to resource URIs. The mapping of SUP ID to resource URI is established via the Discovery mechanisms defined below.

A valid SUP ID is a non-empty string of no more than 128 characters composed of ASCII letters, numbers, or hyphens (regex [a-zA-Z0-9-]), and are produced via the following rules, as defined by the augmented BNF syntax.

section.title: Update ID
section.t: [Ed: Consider changing the name of this to "Revision Id".]

The Update ID is a short opaque string used to disambiguate distinct updates to a content feed. In practice, the last update timestamp of the content feed is a suitable identifier, but clients SHOULD NOT attempt to parse or intepret the contents of the string.

A valid Update ID is a non-empty string of no more than 128 characters composed of ASCII letters, numbers, or hyphens (regex [a-zA-Z0-9-]), and are produced via the following rules, as defined by the augmented BNF syntax.

section.title: Discovery
section.t: This section discusses how a publisher signals the existence of SUP feed.
Feeds SHOULD announce the availabilty of by setting the 'X-SUP-ID' HTTP header, and/or by including a 'atom:link' element, or both.

Use of the 'X-SUP-ID' HTTP header is RECOMMENDED since it works for feed types, but feed consumers SHOULD be prepared for the presence of the link element in addition to, or instead of, the X-SUP-ID header.

section.title: 'X-SUP-ID' HTTP header
section.t: Responses to HTTP requests for content feeds SHOULD include a HTTP Response Header of 'X-SUP-ID' to signal both the URI at which the SUP feed may be polled and the SUP ID of the underlying content feed.
Valid 'X-SUP-ID' headers are produced via the following rules, as defined by the augmented BNF syntax, the URI production grammar defined in , and the above grammar defining the 'sup_id' production.

figure.artwork: x_sup_id_header = "X-SUP-ID" ":" 1*SP updates_uri updates_uri = scheme ":" hier-part [ "?" query ] [ "#" sup_id ]

section.t: For example, the following 'X-SUP-ID' header refers to a SUP Feed at 'http://example.com/sup.json' and indicates that the SUP ID of the resource being returned is '4496672d'.
